slidelink.displaytext: Human Trafficking in the United States

search.slidetext: human trafficking in the u.s. a note of caution to training participants: this course may include readings, media, and discussion around topics such as sexual assault, child sexual abuse, human trafficking, online sexual enticement, domestic violence, and physical violence. hope for justice acknowledges that this content may be difficult and encourages participants to care for their safety and well-being. names have been changed and images are posed by models to protect survivors' identities. start the course start the course start the course the truth and what you can do about it please enter your full name below and click ’start the course’ to begin

by the end of this course, you’ll be able to: define “human trafficking” describe the pervasiveness of and multiple types of human trafficking explain typical victimization factors, pathways, barriers to leaving, and common impacts of human trafficking identify the signs of sex and labor trafficking and exploitation apply recommended calls-to-action continue continue continue

fact or fiction? trafficking doesn’t happen much in the u.s. it always involves transporting people across borders or traveling. people who are trafficked always identify as victims. trafficking victims are usually kidnapped and restrained. human trafficking in the u.s. might not be what you think it is.

casey grew up in small-town nebraska. as a child, she was exposed to drugs and alcohol at home—she lived with her mom and stepfather, who both abused substances. life was hard for casey early on, and it became even harder as she got older… casey’s story click continue to hear the rest of the story. continue continue continue

not quite continue continue continue continue all these are myths about human trafficking in the united states. ready to explore what the real facts are about trafficking? that’s right all these are myths about human trafficking in the united states. ready to explore what the real facts are about trafficking? continue continue continue continue continue continue continue trafficking victims are usually kidnapped and restrained. people who are trafficked always identify as victims. human trafficking always includes transporting people across borders. trafficking doesn’t happen much in the u.s. which of these are common myths about trafficking? choose all that apply and click continue.

150 billion-dollar-a-year global criminal industry international organization for migration walk free foundation international labor organization 25 million victims globally over 400,000 people living in modern slavery in the u.s.
how is human trafficking different from other criminal industries? ? force fraud coercion commercial sex labor click to see the u.s. human trafficking law

trafficking in the united states is: sex trafficking in which a commercial sex act is induced by force, fraud, or coercion, or in which the person induced to perform such act has not attained 18 years of age; or the recruitment, harboring, transportation, provision, or obtaining of a person for labor or services, through the use of force, fraud, or coercion for the purpose of subjection to involuntary servitude, peonage, debt bondage, or slavery. (trafficking victims protection act, 2000) continue continue continue
commercial sex forced labor domestic servitude criminal activity sex trafficking labor trafficking

criminal activity peddling and begging drug dealing domestic servitude housekeeping childcare forced labor hotels restaurants agriculture manufacturing construction beauty services commercial cleaning entertainment and carnivals forestry and fishing healthcare gyms and recreation commercial sex spas massage parlors online gaming and livestreaming bars and clubs brothels pornography production criminal activity criminal activity criminal activity criminal activity domestic servitude domestic servitude domestic servitude domestic servitude forced labor forced labor forced labor forced labor commercial sex commercial sex commercial sex commercial sex continue continue continue click each type to explore more before continuing.

undetected and unreported why? there is no universal victim profile. vulnerabilities push and pull victims into trafficking. abuse drug use instability casey’s vulnerabilities pathway into trafficking coercion fraud force keep victims dependent
human trafficking happens all around us in the u.s. ? could you spot it? have you already encountered it?

you've heard three true survivor stories. make sure you know what to do if you suspect a human trafficking case. report the incident immediately to a local or federal law enforcement agency or organization. even if you are in doubt, report: it could save a victim's life. for safety reasons, do not intervene directly. homeland security investigations: 866-347-2423 polaris: 1-888-373-7888 ncmec: 1-800-the-lost (1-800-843-5678) continue continue continue a true story about the vulnerabilities of unemployment and labor exploitation aleksander a true story about the vulnerabilities of unemployment and labor exploitation aleksander a true story about the vulnerabilities of unemployment and labor exploitation aleksander a true story about decades of domestic servitude tala a true story about decades of domestic servitude tala a true story about decades of domestic servitude tala a true story about the push-and-pull factors of online sex exploitation olivia a true story about the push-and-pull factors of online sex exploitation olivia a true story about the push-and-pull factors of online sex exploitation olivia true survivor stories explore each story to learn more about: how to spot the signs victim vulnerabilities trafficker tactics choose a story. names have been changed and images are posed by models to protect survivors’ identities.

not quite traffickers know how to target the vulnerabilities that push and pull people into exploitation. unemployment, poverty, recent migration, relocation, or displacement, debt, or unstable living are all factors that push people into labor exploitation. the hope for a new opportunity can entice people into victimization through pathways like job postings, direct contact with a trafficker, or even through friends and family members. hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story that’s right traffickers know how to target the vulnerabilities that push and pull people into exploitation. unemployment, poverty, recent migration, relocation, or displacement, debt, or unstable living are all factors that push people into labor exploitation. the hope for a new opportunity can entice people into victimization through pathways like job postings, direct contact with a trafficker, or even through friends and family members. hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story continue continue continue continue hope for a new opportunity laziness insecurity about unemployment and poverty can you spot these in aleksander’s story? choose all that apply and click continue. labor traffickers know how to take advantage of peoples’ vulnerabilities.

not quite labor traffickers use many tactics to create barriers to escape, such as: psychological threat and manipulation debt bondage stealing or withholding the victim’s identifying documents preying on a victim’s fear or distrust of the law social isolation through unfamiliarity with language or surroundings hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story that’s right labor traffickers use many tactics to create barriers to escape, such as: psychological threat and manipulation debt bondage stealing or withholding the victim’s identifying documents preying on a victim’s fear or distrust of the law social isolation through unfamiliarity with language or surroundings hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story continue continue continue continue ensuring isolation stealing identifying documents creating debt bondage psychological threat can you see the tactics that kept aleksander victimized? choose all that apply and click continue. labor traffickers are successful because they ensure their victims can’t escape or leave.
hear what richard schoeberl, ph.d./former fbi and current hope for justice u.s. investigative team leader, says about what happened next. play video play video play video
restoring life aleksander is now safe in the uk. hope for justice helped him receive victim services to restore and stabilize his life. continue continue continue

it’s a myth. an individual can seem to have a means to escape or leave a trafficking situation, but they are still a victim if force, fraud, or coercion is being used to exploit them. even if an individual is being paid, they can still be considered a victim of trafficking. continue continue continue correct, it’s a myth. an individual can seem to have a means to escape or leave a trafficking situation, but they are still a victim if force, fraud, or coercion is being used to exploit them. even if an individual is being paid, they can still be considered a victim of trafficking. continue continue continue myth or fact? if someone has a cell phone, car, or way to escape, they aren’t a victim of trafficking. choose one. myth myth myth myth fact fact fact fact

not quite sex traffickers know how to spot vulnerabilities online and offline. they target children and teens who show emotional or psychological vulnerabilities like: lack of meaningful connection at home low self-esteem desire to make friends who offer attention or excitement other vulnerabilities include: an abusive or unstable homelife, homelessness, involvement in welfare or juvenile justice systems, and substance abuse. see what heather stockdale, hope for justice u.s. program director, has to say about the pathways into sex trafficking. play video play video play video see what heather stockdale, hope for justice u.s. program director, has to say about the pathways into sex trafficking. play video play video play video that’s right sex traffickers know how to spot vulnerabilities online and offline. they target children and teens who show emotional or psychological vulnerabilities like: lack of meaningful connection at home low self-esteem desire to make friends who offer attention or excitement other vulnerabilities include: an abusive or unstable homelife, homelessness, involvement in welfare or juvenile justice systems, and substance abuse. continue continue continue continue she lacked meaningful in-person connections. she spent a lot of time online. it felt good to her to get attention and feel special. she was a teenager. can you spot why olivia might have been vulnerable? choose all that apply and click continue. online traffickers and exploiters know how to target vulnerable individuals.

not quite online and offline grooming is the process of coercing victims into trafficking, especially sex trafficking. exploiters take the time to invest in relationships with victims to build trust and dependency. they often ask for nude photos and personal information to manipulate, coerce, and blackmail victims. hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story that’s right online and offline grooming is the process of coercing victims into trafficking, especially sex trafficking. exploiters take the time to invest in relationships with victims to build trust and dependency. they often ask for nude photos and personal information to manipulate, coerce, and blackmail victims. hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story continue continue continue continue asking for personal information or photos creating dependency ensuring the victim builds trust investing time in the relationship can you spot the grooming methods in this story? choose all that apply and click continue. exploiters and traffickers use specific methods to “groom” victims.

hear what kimberly rushing, lcswa/hope for justice clinical social worker, has to say about olivia's story and why some victims don't leave a grooming or trafficking situation. play video play video play video

life after online exploitation as the investigation unfolded, olivia reached out to her family—who had been informed of the situation by hope for justice. eventually, she worked up the courage to run away from david. law enforcement connected her with victim services to keep her safe and provide her with mental and emotional health support. deeper investigation revealed that david was planning to force and coerce olivia and the other girls into sex trafficking. the case was moved forward into prosecution. continue continue continue “thank you so much for showing me the truth.”

not quite by u.s. law, olivia was a victim of sex trafficking because david was using olivia for sexual activity—sex as well as sexual photos—in exchange for, or a promise of, something of value to her. david provided olivia with the guise of a romantic relationship and a place to live. this is considered commercial sex. because olivia was a minor who, by law, could not consent to commercial sex exchange, she is automatically classified as a victim under u.s. law. continue continue continue that’s right by u.s. law, olivia was a victim of sex trafficking because david was using olivia for sexual activity—sex as well as sexual photos—in exchange for, or a promise of, something of value to her. david provided olivia with the guise of a romantic relationship and a place to live. this is considered commercial sex. because olivia was a minor who, by law, could not consent to commercial sex exchange, she is automatically classified as a victim under u.s. law. continue continue continue continue continue continue continue because there was sexual activity in exchange for something of value because david was preparing to sell olivia into trafficking because olivia was a minor choose all that apply and click continue. online traffickers and exploiters know how to target vulnerable individuals. what do you think? why is olivia’s story a case of sex trafficking, if she hadn’t yet been sold by david?

not quite several barriers kept tala victimized for years. the family used fear and control—psychologically and through physical abuse—to exploit tala and prevent her from leaving. also, because tala was a foreigner who couldn't speak english, didn't know her surroundings, didn't have money, and didn't understand u.s. law, she had multiple barriers that prevented escape. hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story that’s right several barriers kept tala victimized for years. the family used fear and control—psychologically and through physical abuse—to exploit tala and prevent her from leaving. also, because tala was a foreigner who couldn't speak english, didn't know her surroundings, didn't have money, and didn't understand u.s. law, she had multiple barriers that prevented escape. hear more of the story hear more of the story hear more of the story continue continue continue continue physical abuse desire to work with children being a foreigner and not speaking the language lack of money what were barriers that prevented tala from escaping this situation? choose all that apply and click continue. tala was vulnerable and felt like she couldn’t leave.

not quite tala had common victim signs of malnourishment, long work hours, and fatigue. other common labor trafficking signs include: lack of eye contact dirty or limited clothing fear and anxiety untreated injuries unaware of surroundings controlled by the employer others speak for them not free to come or go at will and without their own transportation unpaid or paid very little owing a large debt to a person or business not being in control of identification documents continue continue continue that’s right tala had common victim signs of malnourishment, long work hours, and fatigue. other common labor trafficking signs include: lack of eye contact dirty or limited clothing fear and anxiety untreated injuries unaware of surroundings controlled by the employer others speak for them not free to come or go at will and without their own transportation unpaid or paid very little owing a large debt to a person or business not being in control of identification documents continue continue continue continue continue continue continue she worked excessively long hours. she was elderly. she was malnourished. she was fatigued. what were the signs indicating that tala could be a victim of trafficking? choose all that apply and click continue. there were multiple signs that tala was a domestic slave.

the impacts of a life of servitude the nurse who worked with tala immediately reported her case. when investigators arrived at the family’s home, they searched and found tala shoved into a closet with clothes thrown on her. as investigators tried to rescue tala, she initially didn’t want to leave. living with the family, despite the hardship, was all she had known for so long. eventually, tala was brought to safety and, with the money won in the lawsuit against the family, she was moved into a retirement home. it had taken nearly 40 years for her to be rescued. continue continue continue

hear what richard schoeberl, ph.d./former fbi and current hope for justice u.s. investigative team leader, says about cases like tala's and if rescuing victims is enough to end trafficking. play video play video play video
now that you know about human trafficking in the united states…
one person one person, taking one action, can make a world of difference. one friend one family member one criminal investigator one nurse

ready to take action? small actions have a big impact. take steps now share what you learned follow us on social media host a fundraiser attend an event volunteer donate click on the link or scan the code to choose one action today! https://hopeforjustice.org/get-involved https://hopeforjustice.org/get-involved https://hopeforjustice.org/get-involved certificate certificate certificate certificate
